importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The American Dialect Society named 'enshittification' Word of the Year in 2023, marking its widespread cultural and linguistic adoption as a key concept in internet platform critique.
The article was published on October 21, 2025, providing a timely analysis of internet platform degradation in the context of ongoing public and policy debates about tech monopolies.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article discusses the evolution of internet platforms from 2020 onward, focusing on a pattern of degradation known as enshittification that began in the early 2020s and intensified in recent years.

keyTakeAways: The term 'enshittification' describes how internet platforms like Facebook, Google, Amazon, and Uber degrade from being user-friendly and valuable in their early stages to becoming exploitative and harmful in later stages.

Enshittification occurs in three stages: (1) attracting users with attractive deals and data transparency; (2) favoring business customers at the expense of users; and (3) extracting maximum profit through predatory pricing, data misuse, and algorithmic manipulation.
Platforms use network effects and high switching costs to lock in users and businesses, making it difficult for users to leave or for competition to emerge.

Amazon is accused of cloning products, charging sellers 'junk fees' (up to 51 cents per dollar earned), and manipulating search results to favor its own products, leading to higher prices for consumers.
Facebook is accused of changing user feeds to prioritize ads, forcing publishers to publish more content, and charging publishers to 'boost' content they already want users to see.
Doctorow blames the lack of competition and weak consumer protection regulations — particularly the 'consumer welfare standard' — for allowing platforms to degrade over time.

Doctorow advocates for stronger antitrust enforcement, the end of the consumer welfare standard, and greater interoperability between platforms (e.g., allowing users to transfer data or use third-party apps).
Amazon and Facebook have publicly denied Doctorow’s claims, with Amazon stating its value to customers has improved and that it does not introduce 'junk fees' or manipulate search results.
The article highlights a growing anti-tech monopoly movement, both in the U.S. and internationally, with bipartisan support for policy solutions to reverse enshittification.

namedEntities.name: Cory Doctorow
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Author, internet activist, and journalist who coined the term 'enshittification' and wrote a book with that title.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Doctorow is the central figure in the article, providing the theory and evidence for the degradation of internet platforms through enshittification.

namedEntities.name: enshittification
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A term coined by Cory Doctorow to describe the degradation of internet platforms into exploitative, user-unfriendly systems over time.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The entire article is built around this concept, explaining its stages and how it applies to major platforms like Facebook, Google, Amazon, and Uber.

namedEntities.name: Facebook (Meta)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A social media platform that Doctorow claims has degraded through enshittification.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Facebook is a central example in the article, particularly in how it changed user feeds, prioritized ads, and increased publisher fees to boost ad revenue.

namedEntities.name: Amazon
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An e-commerce platform accused of enshittification through product cloning, junk fees, and search algorithm manipulation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Amazon is a primary target of Doctorow’s critique, with claims about predatory pricing, inflated search results, and high fees for sellers.

namedEntities.name: Uber
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A ride-sharing platform cited by Doctorow as part of the broader pattern of enshittification.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Uber is included as an example of how platforms evolve from user-friendly early stages to exploitative ones, despite not being detailed in depth.

namedEntities.name: Google
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A search engine and internet platform cited by Doctorow as part of the enshittification pattern.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Google is referenced in the context of user data use and ad targeting, though not as a primary example in the detailed analysis.

namedEntities.name: American Dialect Society
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An organization that recognized 'enshittification' as its Word of the Year in 2023.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Its recognition validates the cultural and linguistic impact of the term, showing its acceptance beyond academic or niche circles.

namedEntities.name: Merriam-Webster
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A dictionary publisher that included 'enshittification' in its dictionary despite its offensive connotations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This demonstrates the widespread cultural and linguistic acceptance of the term as a serious analytical concept.

namedEntities.name: Institute for Local Self-Reliance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A non-profit research and advocacy organization that provided data supporting Doctorow’s claims about Amazon’s junk fees.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The organization is cited as a source for the data suggesting Amazon takes up to 51 cents per dollar from sellers.

namedEntities.name: consumer welfare standard
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A legal doctrine used in antitrust cases that evaluates monopolistic behavior based on consumer price increases.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Doctorow argues this standard fails to address platform degradation and lacks accountability for user harm.

namedEntities.name: Planet Money
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A podcast series by NPR that covers topics like antitrust and internet platform regulation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article references Planet Money as a source of related content and context, showing broader media engagement with the issue.

namedEntities.name: right-to-exit
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A policy proposal suggested by Doctorow to allow users to take their data or content with them when leaving a platform.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is presented as a potential policy solution to break user lock-in and promote platform accountability.

namedEntities.name: interoperability
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A technical principle allowing different products or services to work together, as applied to tech platforms.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Doctorow argues that companies have created artificial barriers to interoperability to maintain dominance, and that regulation could fix this.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article explores the theory of 'enshittification,' a concept introduced by internet activist and author Cory Doctorow, which describes how internet platforms like Facebook, Google, Amazon, and Uber degrade from user-friendly, innovative services into exploitative and harmful systems over time. Doctorow outlines three stages of enshittification: (1) initial user acquisition with attractive deals and data transparency; (2) favoring business customers at the expense of users through ad targeting and content curation; and (3) extracting maximum profit through predatory pricing, algorithmic manipulation, and high fees. The article criticizes platforms for using network effects and high switching costs to lock in users and businesses, and for lacking competition and adequate regulation. Doctorow argues that weak antitrust enforcement and the consumer welfare standard enable these harmful practices. He proposes policy solutions, including stronger antitrust laws, the 'right-to-exit' for users, and increased interoperability between platforms. Amazon and Facebook have responded by denying the claims, but the article highlights a growing public and political movement to address platform monopolization and reverse enshittification.
title: A theory why the internet is going down the toilet
